com.martinandersson.javaee.jpa.entitymanagers.containermanaged

Class TransactionScopedTest

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.martinandersson.javaee.jpa.entitymanagers.AbstractJTAEntityManagerTest
      • com.martinandersson.javaee.jpa.entitymanagers.containermanaged.AbstractContainerManagedEntityManagerTest
        • com.martinandersson.javaee.jpa.entitymanagers.containermanaged.TransactionScopedTest

  • public class TransactionScopedTest
extends AbstractContainerManagedEntityManagerTest
    Container-managed entity managers may have a persistence context that is scoped to the current/active JTA transaction1.

    When the transaction finish, the persistence context is destroyed and all entities in it become detached.

    Container-managed entity managers uses a transaction-scoped persistence context by default. Entity changes are flushed to database when the transaction commit.

    The persistence context of container-managed entity managers propagate to other application components and their container-managed entity managers together with the active JTA transaction2 (independent of whether it was the container or the bean that started the transaction).

    ..but there is an exception to this rule. A @Stateful bean that uses an extended persistence context cannot be the target of such a propagation. You'll find more test regarding this topic in ExtendedTest

    Usage of the entity manager outside a transaction

    JPA 2.1, section "3.1.1 EntityManager Interface": 
    
 
     The persist, merge, remove, and refresh methods must be invoked within a
     transaction context when an entity manager with a transaction-scoped
     persistence context is used. If there is no transaction context, the
     javax.persistence.TransactionRequiredException is thrown.
     
     [..]
 
     The find method (provided it is invoked without a lock or invoked with
     LockModeType.NONE) and the getReference method are not required to be
     invoked within a transaction. If an entity manager with
     transaction-scoped persistence context is in use, the resulting entities
     will be detached[.]
    JPA 2.1, section "7.9.1 Container Responsibilities": 
    
 
     The container must throw the TransactionRequiredException if a
     transaction-scoped persistence context is used and the EntityManager
     persist, remove, merge, or refresh method is invoked when no transaction
     is active.

    Note 1

    For more info about JTA, see ../entitymanagers/package-info.java.

    Note 2

    JPA 2.1 specification, section "7.8.2 Container Managed Persistence Contexts": 
    
 
     Exactly how the container maintains the association between persistence
     context and JTA transaction is not defined.
    Author:
    Martin Andersson (webmaster at martinandersson.com)

    • Method Detail

      • containerJTAPersist_okay

        public void containerJTAPersist_okay()
        Do EntityManager.persist() within a container-started transaction.

        Expect a positive outcome.

      • beanJTAPersist_okay

        public void beanJTAPersist_okay()
                         throws Exception
        Do EntityManager.persist() within a bean-started transaction.

        Expect a positive outcome.

        Note here that the entity manager's context will join the transaction and therefore flush to database even if it is the bean itself that has started a transaction.

        The transaction must have been started before first use of the entity manager.

        Throws:
        Exception - never

      • persistWithoutTransaction_crash

        public void persistWithoutTransaction_crash()
                                     throws Throwable
        Do EntityManager.persist() without an active transaction.

        Expect the worst because a transaction-scoped entity manager must be within the scope of an active transaction before he's able to do persist().

        Throws:
        Throwable - hopefully
        See Also:
        TransactionScopedTest

      • persistenceContextPropagatedToTransactionScoped

        public void persistenceContextPropagatedToTransactionScoped()
        Firstly, call bean1 that persist product. Then make bean1 do a nested call to bean2 and assert that the persistence context was propagated.

      • persistenceContextNotPropagated_inbetweenTransactions

        public void persistenceContextNotPropagated_inbetweenTransactions()
                                                           throws Throwable
        Call bean1 that persist and return product to our client code. Then forward the product reference to bean2 that try to remove the product using EntityManager.remove().

        EntityManager.remove() require a managed entity as argument.

        Our client code has no transaction that is inherited by bean2. One transaction will be started and committed by bean1. Another transaction will be started and committed by bean2. Inbetween, the product entity we pass will become detached and we expect that bean2 who call EntityManager.remove() will fail utterly hard.

        Is there a solution we could write in bean2's code? Yes. Issue a DELETE query instead of using EntityManager.remove() or make the entity managed first by calling, in order of preference, EntityManager.getReference()1, EntityManager.find(), or EntityManager.merge()2.

        Note 1

        EntityManager.getReference() return a managed entity, see JPA 2.1, section "3.2.8 Managed Instances". But, GlassFish and WildFly has differences regarding getReference(). See test cases that use this method in QueryingForEntitiesTest.

        Note 2

        EntityManager.merge() return the managed reference. Reference passed in as argument is left as a detached entity.
        Throws:
        Throwable - hopefully

      • persistenceContextNotPropagated_transactionNotInherited

        public void persistenceContextNotPropagated_transactionNotInherited()
        Equivalent to last test, only this will make bean1 call into bean2 who suspend the transaction.

        It is expected that the persistence context is not propagated.

      • getBeanBeingTested

        protected final EntityManagerExposer getBeanBeingTested()
        Description copied from class: AbstractJTAEntityManagerTest
        Returns the target bean that offer an exposed EntityManager.

        One must not assume anything about the state of the entity manager's persistence context after this method has been called.

        Specified by:
        getBeanBeingTested in class AbstractJTAEntityManagerTest
